726868f-c.text:
Hobart Street, east side, just south of 30th Avenue, showing the old Banta farmhouse from 1873 to 1909. The
farm comprised 23 acres in 1891.
P. L. Sperr  June 23, 1932
NO REPRODUCTIONS  Views 1,2,3

726869f-a.text:
Hobart Street, east side, just south of 30th Avenue, viewing north toward the latter and showing an old farmhouse and farm. It was owned by the Banta Family from 1873 to 1909. Hobart Street, here, is the former Old Bowery Road which marked the boundary between the towns of Newtown and
Long Island City.
P. L. Sperr  June 23, 1932
NO REPRODUTTIONS  Views 1,2,3

726869f-c.text:
Hobart Street, east side, just south of 30th Avenue, viewing north toward the latter and showing an old farmhouse and farm. It was owned by the Banta Family from 1873 to 1909. Hobart Street, here, is the former Old Bowery Road which marked the boundary between the towns of Newtown and
Long Island City.
P. L. Sperr  June 23, 1932
NO REPRODUTTIONS  Views 1,2,3

726869f-b.text:
Hobart Street, east side, just south of 30th Avenue, viewing north toward the latter and showing an old farmhouse and farm. It was owned by the Banta Family from 1873 to 1909. Hobart Street, here, is the former Old Bowery Road which marked the boundary between the towns of Newtown and
Long Island City.
P. L. Sperr  June 23, 1932
NO REPRODUTTIONS  Views 1,2,3

726867f-a.text:
Hobart Street (foreground), at the S.E. corner of Thirtieth Ave., showing the Purdy homestead, the propemty of the heirs of Cornelius Purdy in 1852. One Nancy Banta was the owner from 1891 to 1909. This house was erected prior to the Revolutionary War and was still standing
in 1927.
Arthur White.

726870f-c.text:
Hobart Street (dirt road), east side, north from 55th Street to Thirtieth Avenue, showing in a set of 4 views an old Rapelje house later known as the Cornelius Purdy farmhouse. The history of ownership is that CorneliaNyckoff married Captain Cornelius Rapelje who in 1758 purchased this farm from his father-in-law. Mary Ranelje, daughter of Captain Cornelius, rarried David Purdy after whom the house, which was erected in 1770, was named. Other owners of this house and farmland were heirs of Cornelius Purdy
1852, and the Banta family from 1860-1891.
April 1923
Views 1,2, and 3
View 4: May 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
